After cleaning the reactor, an overpressure of approx. 0.6 bar was applied in order to drain the solution. This triggered the reactor emergency pressure release rupture disc. Volatile components were fed into a catch tank. Any emissions were removed using a wet scrubber. The cleaning solution is composed of a mixture of ethanol and water (4:1). Since the solution is used multiple times, impurities are to be expected (approx. 10 - 20%). The impurities are composed of phenol and formaldehyde. We estimate that at the time of the event, the gas phase was composed of formaldehyde, phenol, acetone, ethanol and water.   The cleaning solution is composed of a mixture of ethanol and water. Since the solution is used multiple times, impurities are to be expected (approx. 10 - 20%). The impurities are composed of phenol and formaldehyde.   We estimate that at the time of the event, the gas phase was composed of formaldehyde, phenol, ethanol and water.   Safety function: Rupture disc for emergency pressure release in the event of overpressure of 1.5 bar in the reactor.

Safe shutdown of an underground natural gas storage facility and release of methane into the atmosphere While gas was being withdrawn from the site, safe shutdown with venting was automatically triggered at 7:20 p.m. following a voltage drop on the 24VDC network powering the safety programmable logic controller (safety PLC) controlling the site’s safe shutdown system. The triggering of this safety procedure caused the release of 25,000 m³ of natural gas, or 16 t of methane.

Final_Category_Path: equipment > static equipment > piping > valv > valve left open by mistake
Consolidated_Path: equipment > static equipment > piping > valv > valve left open by mistake
Description_Full: Release of phosgene At the time of the serious accident, the concerned phosgene production unit was out of service, under vacuum, and contained no phosgene. In the meantime, phosgene production was in progress in other similar units. The concerned unit was connected to the ongoing phosgene production through a pipeline. That pipeline connection was blocked with a paddle blind, that had been placed between the flanges under the remote-operated pneumatic ball valve. By management's decision, the paddle blind had to be removed. The task was carried out by a system operator and a trainee system operator (later became victim), supervised by the shift supervisor.  Before the work, they checked that the unit was under vacuum, and no phosgene was present. After loosening the bolts connecting the flanges, the paddle blind could only be partially removed, it was stuck between the flanges.  While he tried to remove the stuck paddle blind without a proper tool, the trainee system operator unintentionally displaced a test screw on the remote-operated pneumatic valve and opened it partially. This resulted in a phosgene release. The trainee system operator used an air-purifying respirator instead of the required compressed air breathing apparatus. The toxic gas immediately got through the filter of the air-purifying respirator, causing the trainee system operator to inhale, also contaminate his workwear.  They immediately rushed to the control room, where the shift supervisor instructed the system operators to shut down the technology.  Afterward, the shift supervisor checked the status of this pneumatic ball valve on the PLC screen.  It displayed failure while receiving a closing command. The trainee system operator, apart from coughing, appeared to be in a good condition. Also, he verified that he is not feeling unwell. At the establishment, there was a 7/24 emergency service (local firefighter brigade and first aid service). In the control room, the system operators and the shift supervisor questioned the trainee system operator if he needed first aid, but he did not request it, so they did not notify the emergency service. By the end of the shift (at 23:00) and on his way home, the trainee system operator was feeling better. Soon after arriving home, however, his condition deteriorated significantly. The shift supervisor pick him up and took him to the hospital. After a medical examination, he was admitted to the intensive care unit, where he died in the early hours of the morning.
Consolidated_Path_Full: equipment > static equipment > piping > valv > valve left open by mistake

Description_Full: Storm Damage at Evos Malta Ltd. A severe storm hit the Maltese Islands with gale force winds, high waves and heavy rainfall for a number of hours. The company took the necessary precautions by halting all operations, removing berthed ships, emptying all pipelines from fuel and evacuating all personnel. The storm was so severe that most pipelines on the jetties, metal structures, lighting poles and loading arm were badly damaged and rendered unoperational. The storage tanks and their associated infrastructure, and fire fighting systemsupplying the storage tanks was undamaged. There were no fuel spills and no one was injured.
Combustion of smokeless powder The dropping of a 70 kg handling package on the floor, which contained dry smokeless powder, caused the ignition and combustion.

Final_Category_Path: incident type > fire > liquid substance fire
Consolidated_Path: incident type > fire > liquid substance fire
Description_Full: Spontaneous ignition of an ISO shipping container at a container terminal Conditions: Normal operations – middle shift   Trigger: The trigger event was the spontaneous combustion of sodium dithionite with atmospheric oxygen, which had escaped from a damaged part of the drum. The high summer temperature combined with a higher humidity level favoured the chemical reaction. It is highly likely that the drum was damaged when the container was loaded using the forklift.   Course of events from 23 August 2022 to 24 August 2022: Smoke emission in a sealed shipping container in the F3 operating area in position 2 approx. 2.5 hours after it was placed there. Alarm, see No 3.3. Provision of relevant substance data for the container in question. After arrival of the Mannheim fire brigade, and in consultation with them, the container was removed from the stack and placed on the terminal track to enable rescue workers to tackle it. Decomposition of sodium dithionite, release of sulphur dioxide as yellowy white cloud. The container was then cooled with water by the fire brigades to slow down the reaction inside the container. Dispersion of the smoke cloud. Use of the turbo extinguisher of the on-site fire brigade of the establishment as part of the ‘transport accident information and assistance system’ (Transport-Unfall-Informations- und Hilfeleistungssystem – TUIS) operation. As a precaution, a radius of 200 m around the container was indicated for emergency workers; this was subsequently reduced to 50 m. Business operations at the container terminal were suspended when the fire brigade intervention began. Other neighbouring establishments were also affected. Residents in the immediate vicinity were evacuated. Upon enquiries with the Mannheim fire brigade, it was stated that approximately 80 people were affected by the evacuation, of which approximately 30 people were given accommodation for one night and were able to return to their homes the following morning. As a precaution, roads and railways in a radius of up to 1 300 m around the terminal were closed, as were the Mühlauhafen port and the Rhine plus the Kurt-Schumacher bridge, and residents were told to keep their windows and doors closed. The warning to the directly affected population telling them to keep windows and doors closed was given on 23 August 2022 at 16:11. The additional warning also not to leave buildings was given on 23 August 2022 at 17.34. More specific guidance was issued on 24 August 2022 at 01:50 to the effect that no measurements of concern could be detected and that doors and windows should remain closed if possible, purely as a precaution. The crane operator and 16 members of the police force were taken to see a doctor as a precaution, but were able to leave the hospital immediately. 2 police officers were kept in hospital overnight for monitoring. Course of events from 25 August 2022: In consultation with the fire brigades involved and product owners, the decision was taken to initially continue to cool the container using water. There were no other ways of stopping the chemical reaction clearly taking place inside the container. Operations at the terminal were resumed for the most part by the late afternoon of 26 August 2022, with the exception of the area around the damaged container. The road Werfthallenstraße in front of the terminal was largely re-opened to traffic. The container continued to be cooled until 31 August 2022. That afternoon the container was opened after the contents had been viewed using endoscopes through openings. Around 17:00 it was possible to begin unloading the container. Using a telescoping excavator, the drums were unloaded into skip containers, which were taken to the BASF disposal facility. The recovery work was paused on 31 August 2022 at around 24:00 and resumed on 1 September 2022 at around 16:00. The last drum was unloaded from the container on 1 September 2022 at around 22:30.   Safety function: Alerting and evacuating staff and alerting the fire brigade according to the alarm plan. Cooling the container until the afternoon of 31 August 2022.
Consolidated_Path_Full: incident type > fire > liquid substance fire

Final_Category_Path: incident type > fire > vapor substance fire
Consolidated_Path: incident type > fire > vapor substance fire

Description_Full: Release of ammonia at a refrigeration system (ice water pre-cooling) at a food manufacturer Ammonia gas (NH3) escaped through a loose screw fitting and was detected by an overhead gas detection system.All three alert thresholds were triggered. As a result, the plant was shut down and the fire service alerted along with the in-house refrigeration technician (internal and external). The plant’s fire service sealed off the affected area until the arrival of the external fire service and a hazardous material (‘hazmat’) response team was also summoned. Safety functions: Gas warning system shut down in accordance with set thresholds, Fire service alerted immediately, No personnel in hazardous area, Chamber secured by locking system, Switch to waste water treatment plant emergency collection basin, Chamber with oil barrier, Access road closed, Monitoring at specific operating points in consultation with the fire service.

Release of nitric acid (HNO3) in an electroplating plant During extension work on a control panel, the specialist contractor accidentally disconnected a neutral conductor.This led to three extraction units being turned off via a relay, but this was not clearly displayed visually in the control room.As a result, the electroplating hall fogged up very quickly, which triggered the gas detection system. Because of the dual protection of the electrical cabinets with smoke intake systems at the request of fire insurers, the penetrating fog led to the detection of a presumed fire in a cabinet, whereupon the fire detection system alerted the fire service. After the faults had been repaired, normal operations could resume. Safety functions:The gas detection system triggered an alarm, prompting all staff to exit the building (full evacuation).

Hydrogen explosion and hydrogen fire in a chemical plant hydrogen supply Discharge of a large amount of hydrogen from a trailer into the site compressed air network, ignition of the explosive atmosphere in a compressed air user (solids silo, contents: no incident substances).

Hydrogen explosion and hydrogen fire in a chemical plant hydrogen supply Discharge of a large amount of hydrogen from a trailer into the site compressed air network, ignition of the explosive atmosphere in a compressed air user (solids silo, contents: no incident substances).

Dangerous chemical reaction at a waste recycling plant The spread of toxic gases generated in a dangerous reaction took place on 19th of September 2022 at a waste processing and recycling plant in Järvenpää, Finland. Two employees were exposed to the gas, resulting in the death of one of them. The chain of events leading to the accident started when an attempt was made to remove a precipitate adhered to a reactor vessel using mixed acid waste containing hydrogen fluoride and nitric acid. The reaction between the precipitate and mixed acid waste generated toxic gases that spread from the reactor vessel to the process facility through an open sampling connection. The employees were exposed to gas when they attempted to stop the dangerous reaction.

Description_Full: RO/001/2023 - Gasoline release trough pipeline On 01.05.2023 in the tanks park installation (gasoline pipeline area), on the section of the push pipeline (gasoline), DN 250, placed near the holding vat of tank T64, during the operation of removing the pneumatic armour respectively removing the mechanical shutter from the pipeline by contractor (Kremsmueller Romania SRL and Elket SRL), there was a gasoline spill (liquid and gas) followed by a fire, as a result of which there were 3 victims; 2 of them were hospitalized with various degrees of burning, one of them died in hospital.

RO/001/2023 - Gasoline release trough pipeline On 01.05.2023 in the tanks park installation (gasoline pipeline area), on the section of the push pipeline (gasoline), DN 250, placed near the holding vat of tank T64, during the operation of removing the pneumatic armour respectively removing the mechanical shutter from the pipeline by contractor (Kremsmueller Romania SRL and Elket SRL), there was a gasoline spill (liquid and gas) followed by a fire, as a result of which there were 3 victims; 2 of them were hospitalized with various degrees of burning, one of them died in hospital.

Pipeline explosion in ammonia plant At 01:02, during the start-up manoeuvres of the Ammonia III plant, near the synthesis column, the weld cord breaks over the entire circumference, made between a section of vertical pipe and a connecting elbow with a horizontal pipe. At the breaking of the welding cord, the pressure of the released gas generated the detachment of some metal pipe fixing parts, generating mechanical sparks that ignited the explosive mixture. After igniting the mixture, the burning rate increased explosively, producing: deflagration in the mass of the cloud, pressure wave and a flame front that affected the thermal insulation of the pipes near the cut pipe and generated a thermal radiative field.  After the explosion, the flames remained active at the level of the rupture, where the synthesis gas was still released. The Ammonia III plant was shut down immediately, the synthesis loop was depressurized and inertized with nitrogen. The fire was extinguished in approximately 2 hours by the prompt intervention of firefighters from the internal Service for Emergency Situations (SPSU) Azomures and external firefighters from Mures Inspectorate for Emergency Situations. Details: Given the specificity of ammonia production technology, restarting the plant after a shutdown for a long period of time usually takes about 3 days, most of the phases of the technological process requiring heating and activation of catalysts in a well-defined sequence and procedured at the level of the economic operator. At the time of the event, the last manoeuvres were carried out to complete the process of commissioning the installation and the resumption of the production process and the installation was within normal operating parameters in terms of temperatures, pressures and flow rates, according to the process diagrams recorded in the control room; the syngas parameters were: 73% hydrogen content, pressure 135 bar, temperature 390°C.

Explosion and fire in a rafinery hydrofining plant On 2 July, at 12:16, on the Petromidia platform, at the Hydrofining Plant (HPM) was an explosion followed by a fire. Based on the analysis of the accident it was found that during the technological process, a pump feeding the reaction section in tank 122-V8 failed. Following the shutdown of this pump, a series of other events occured which led to the explosion followed by fire of tank 122-V8, as described: - after the pump stopped, the flow in the system dropped and the sense valve cracked; - the non functioning of the sense valve led to the increase in pressure in the tank 122-V8; the pressure in the reactor reversed the technological flow and led to the supply of the tank, 122-V8 with mixture of diesel and hydrogen; - a series of communication alarms followed at the lower level transducer from the 122-V8 tank continuing with maximum level alarm to the 122-V8 vessel; - the following alarms are from the pressure in the tank that first signals maximum, followed in the same second by a minimum alarm (at this moment the explosion has already taken place). As a result of the explosion there were three fires in three directions: one at the exploding tank, one at a cracked pipe in the gas fractionation area and one on the ground in the tank area.

Final_Category_Path: incident type > explosion > runaway reaction and explosion
Consolidated_Path: incident type > explosion > runaway reaction and explosion

Description_Full: Fluid Catalytic Cracking Unit Jet Fire The accident occured in the 'Fluid Catalytic Cracking Unit'. Fluid catalytic cracking  is a chemical process that uses a catalyst to create new, smaller molecules from larger molecules to make LPG, gasoline and distillate fuels. The catalyst is a solid material that behave as a fluid when aerated. Because the catalyst is fluid, the process continuously circulates this material between a reactor and regenerator. Operating at high temperatures and moderate pressures, the catalyst is mixed with atomized hydrocarbon feed in the reactor riser. Vaporization of the feed and supplemental lift gases force the material up the riser to a termination device that, along with the reactor cyclons, separates the reaction products from the entrained catalyst. The spent catalyst falls into an annulus where steam "strips" away any remaining hydrocarbons and the reaction products travel from the cyclones to a fractionation (destillation) column for separation into desired components. During cracking, process material ("coke") is deposited on the catalyst; this material reduces cracking activity and is removed during regeneration where air is used to burn the "coke". This also provides the heat for the process. Slide valves, ensuring a "plug" of catalyst in the connecting pipes, play an important role to avoid migration of hydrocarbons into the regenerator's oxygen environment or migration of oxygen into the reactor's hydrocarbon atmosphere. A large crack appeared in the middle section of Main Fractionator. The released hydrocarbon/steam cloud ignited and created a jet fire. The air blower was immediately stopped, emergency staff was mobilized and the intense fire was extinguished 20 minutes later by the steam present in the main fractionator whilst the fire brigade cooled the surrounding equipment. Production personnel had noticed a loud noise and a small fire at a gasket shortly before the rupture and had left the installation in time.

Final_Category_Path: equipment > process equipment > cracking equipment > catalytic cracker

Fire in electrolysis plant A fire occured on a "production group" of electrolysis cells in the electrolysis plant, operators tried extinguish the fire at the same time that they alerted SOS, but the fire could not be exstinguished and the rescue service arrived at plant but their fire fighting measures were not enough and operators and emergency services evacuated and soon the plant was engulfed in flames. Firefighting then continued for many hours without the electrolysis plant being able to be saved and efforts were instead concentrated on saving adjacent operations and equipment at the smelter. The entire plant was destroyed in the fire and a lot of smoke spread around the plant and a lot of electrolyte is placed by the plant. (~4500m3 sulfuric acid mixture) No one was injured during the fire or during subsequent extinguishing work. Crisis management and crisis support for affected personnel has been initiated.

Crisis management and crisis support for affected personnel has been initiated.

VKG OIL On August 13, 2024, at 20:45, during the unloading of PDTRK (fine-dispersed ash-rich fuel) in bunker room B-1, a mixture of PDTRK and hot water leaked from one section of the bunker into the area where the truck was located. The vapors of oil shale gasoline contained in the liquid ignited at 20:46, setting fire to the truck (including the person inside) and the room. The ignition of the vapors caused an overpressure, leading to structural damage. The material loaded into the bunker and trucks consists of 40% oil shale ash, with the remaining portion composed of oil shale residues (including gasoline). The material enters the bunker at a temperature of 50–60°C. It emits highly flammable vapors, which do not escape from the bunker due to the airtightness of its upper section. To prevent the risk of explosion, the bunker is regularly filled with nitrogen to reduce oxygen concentration, which is monitored by dedicated sensors. The lower part of the bunker remains sealed by a semi-liquid, clay-like mass, which is always maintained at least halfway full. The accident is linked to liquid that entered and later exited the system. The origin of the liquid is under investigation, as it could have entered the bunker from two separate buildings. However, no anomalies in the production process were detected in either facility.

HD - Terpena - Explosion followed by fire at a factory producing essential oils Beginning: on 12.09.2017, around 16:30. Manifestation: explosion followed by fire,with rapid horizontal and vertical extension both in the production building and in other buildings on the site where hazardous substances were stored. The County Inspectorate for Emergency Situations (CIES) dispatcher was notified about the event at 16.49 trough emergency number 112. 10 min. later fire fighters from CIES were at the scene. The intervention of emergency services was difficult due to the release of a large amount of black smoke, high thermal radiation and the imminent danger of further explosions. Foam cannons, foam generating hoses for extinguishing and water discharge hoses for protection were used. Through out the action the intervention was predominantly defensive, acting from a distance with water and foam cannons from the vehicles. The county emergency service received reinforcements from neighboring counties. The fire was extinguished on 13.09.2017 at 12:00. The damage was major, starting with the building Gf+4, where all the installations and materials in the production area, including most of the administrative area, wereburned. The fire also spread to neighbouring buildings, warehouses with packaging and hazardous substances, which also burned.

Final_Category_Path: incident type > fire > vapor substance fire
Consolidated_Path: incident type > fire > vapor substance fire

Description_Full: Release of carbon disulphide (CS2) in a chemical company Conditions: Shutdown process for maintenance.   Trigger: Connecting the plant to the drinking water network in order to fill the tanks with water during the planned shutdown (cold-commissioning with water). Because of the overpressure, contaminated water was discharged into the drinking water network of the industrial estate. As a result, there was a carbon disulphide leak in the sanitary room of the neighbouring plant, which injured two people. Safety function: There was no safety system to prevent backflow.   Initially, water for cold-commissioning in the plant had been obtained by means of hoses from an internal process water network, which was not part of the drinking water supply. No system separators had therefore been installed that could have prevented backflow from the plant into the drinking water network in such a situation. Because of the corrosion behaviour of the process water, a switch was then made to the drinking water from the industrial estate drinking water network, which is also used by the neighbouring companies. The company staff responsible for plant safety was not consulted during this switchover process. As a result, the risks of this incident were not assessed, either, and the necessity of using a system separator was not recognised.

Major naphtha leak due to sinking floating roof A bottom leak was detected on Monday, June 24, 2024, in one of the storage tanks, which at the time was filled with approximately 12,000 tons of naphtha. Naphtha leaked into the bund at the bottom of the tank and activated a gas detector, after which an operator went to the site and noted the leak. The internal emergency plan was launched, and the external fire brigade and civil protection service came to the scene. Initially, naphtha was pumped through the low suction as much as possible to two other tanks in the terminal. Water was also put in the tank, causing water to leak out instead of naphtha. The bund was covered with foam. There was enormous odor nuisance, as far as 40 km from the terminal. On Tuesday morning, June 25, 2024, drone images revealed that there was also naphtha above the floating roof of the tank, which explained the enormous odor nuisance. From then on, the tank roof was also covered with foam. It soon became clear that the tank's floating roof had sunk completely. The initial plan was to expel all the naphtha to above the floating roof and then pump it through the roof drain to another tank, but after about two days it became clear that this operation would take too long to ensure the integrity of the earthen walls of the bund. Since on some spots it was found that product was leaking trough the earth dikes and the integrity of the dikes became questionable because they were completely soaked with water and leaked naphtha. This were still old earth dikes without any form of waterproofing of reinforcement in them. It was then decided to drain the remaining contents of the tank into the bund through the leak in the bottom. As soon as the liquid level dropped below the floating roof, nitrogen was pumped into the tank to control the explosion risk, which was not easy given the immense space below the roof.   Finally, over a period of about five days, the remaining contents of the tank completely emptied into the bund through the leak in the bottom. The total amount of naphtha that leaked into the bund is estimated at 2,750 tons (treshold for reporting to the EC is 1,250 tons). The mixture of foam, water and naphtha in the bund was pumped into two other tanks in the terminal, which were also partially filled with naphtha. As the bund could not be entered, this was done with mobile pumps and cranes. After pumping was stopped, a layer of sand was sprayed on the contaminated bottom of the bund to maximize odor control. During the entire intervention fluorine-free foam was used, which had to be constantly topped up because it was much less resistant to water and wind than conventional firefighting foam. Supply was critical at one point, so foam was even transported by train from other facilities. In total, more than 1,000 m³ of firefighting foam was used.

Final_Category_Path: caus > process upsets > overpressure > internal overpressure (solid material)
Description_Full: Explosive detachment of a pulp storage tank roof at a fluting mill Mondi Powerflute Oy is a semi-chemical fluting mill with a production process based on ammonia. A similar process is not known to be used elsewhere in Finland. An extensive upgrade was carried out at the mill between 2021 and 2023, and it was completed in November 2023.  Approximately 230 employees of its own and employees of several subcontractors work at the mill. The mill does not fall under the Seveso classification, instead the plant is under surveillance of competent authority because of Finnish legislation. The mill’s board machine had operational issues in the morning on 4 November 2024, and the machine stopped. It was decided to interrupt and shut down pulp production for the duration of the downtime. At 11:56 a.m. on the day of the incident, an explosion and an uncontrolled increase of pressure occurred in the pulp storage tank at the end of the shutdown of the fibre line. As a result of the explosion, the pulp storage tank’s roof was detached, and it landed on to the roof of the adjacent mill building, causing damage. Loose pieces also landed on to the ground around the mill area. The accident did not cause any personal injury. The immediate cause of the accident was gas combustion and sudden pressure increase within the pulp storage tank. Hydrogen was formed in the tank during the process, and it reached an explosive concentration in the gas mixture with ammonia. The gas mixture was most likely ignited by a static spark. The changes to process chemistry after the mill upgrade and the microbiological conditions in the white water system increased the formation of hydrogen and hydrogen-ammonia gas mixture in the process. The accident was also affected by the shutdown conditions of the fibre line and the structures of the white water system and pulp storage tank

Final_Category_Path: caus > equipment failure > mechanical equipment failure > accidental opening > operation started when containment open
Consolidated_Path: caus > equipment failure > mechanical equipment failure > accidental opening > operation started when containment open

Description_Full: Ignition of smokeless powder A fine-grained smokeless powder ignited in a production building.The event caused the demolition of the roof, the entrance wall of the building and the technological equipment. Fragments were scattered up to a distance of 50 meters.

Ethylene release due to thawgasline rupture On March 21, 2025, a process safety incident occurred during testing of the emergency system (venting tests) prior to startup, resulting in the rupture of a high-pressure ethylene thaw gas line. The rupture was audible from the control room; no personnel was in the immediate area. Seven gas detectors alarmed; the release lasted ~40 minutes. Approximately 3.6 tons of ethylene were released into the atmosphere via the rupture. An additional 3.6 tons was vented to the atmosphere to a safe location (60 m high stack).

Fire and substance release in a biogas plant Operational procedure: Maintenance and repair Operating conditions: At the [time] of the event, Digestate Store 1 had been emptied and filled with gas because of planned maintenance. Trigger/sequence of events: An external company had been contracted to replace the level sensors in Digestate Store 1. The old level sensor could not be removed from the blocked guide pipe. In order to reach the old sensor, the external company staff opened the manhole using an impact driver. The person working directly next to the manhole set the impact driver aside once the manhole was opened, and moved several meters away from the opening. Then, a large flame could be seen over the digestate store, generating perceptibly strong heat. Safety functions: Alerting the institutions listed in the emergency plan (fire brigade, police etc.), immediately cutting electrical power, withdrawing all persons involved from the danger zone.

Fire in a warehouse with chemical products for swimming pool water treatment  The fire started in the early morning in a warehouse that mainly stored trichroloisocianuric acid in tablets and granulated. There were no personnel present in the warehouse. The decomposition of the acid tablets caused the formation of a toxic cloud that affected the exterior of the facilities. Other materials, as small plastic containrs, wooden palets and wrapping plastics also were involved. The investigations carried out to date do not show any evidence of batteries presence at the site when the accident ocurred

Final_Category_Path: consequenc > fire > liquid substance fire > tank fire
Consolidated_Path: consequenc > fire > liquid substance fire > tank fire

Description_Full: Explosion in a tank during welding works While maintenance work was being carried out on a tank, an explosion occurred that caused one fatality and one serious injury. Both workers. The objetive was to seal a hole detected in the roof of the tank Then, a deflagration occurred that blew off the roof and caused a fire inside the tank. The tank had storaged Methyl Acetate (Flammable Liquid. Cat 2) and had not been inerted previosly.
